In chemistry and the biological sciences, a 'dehydration reaction' is usually
defined as a chemical reaction that involves the loss of a water molecule from
the reacting molecule. Dehydration reactions are a subset of elimination
reactions. Because the hydroxyl group (âOH) is a poor leaving group, having a
BrÃ¸nsted acid catalyst often helps by protonating the hydroxyl group to give the
better leaving group, âOH 2+ . The reverse of a dehydration
reaction is a hydration reaction. Common dehydrating agents used in organic
synthesis includes concentrated sulfuric acid, concentrated phosphoric acid, hot
aluminium oxide and hot ceramic.

Dehydration reactions and dehydration synthesis have the same meaning, and are
often used interchangeably. Two monosaccharides, such as glucose and fructose,
can be joined together (to form sucrose) using dehydration synthesis. The new
molecule, consisting of two monosaccharides, is called a disaccharide.

The process of hydrolysis is the reverse reaction, meaning that the water is
recombined with the two hydroxyl groups and the disaccharide reverts to being
monosaccharides.

In the related condensation reaction water is released from two different
reactants.
